videos.question: Do autistic people usually eat differently?
videos.transcription: So this is something that I am very up and down with.I think for me it shows up in the waythat I have certain safe foods.So I think the best way to describe it isa lot of the time, if I'm just going about my life,if I'm doing normal things,then I have a fairly normal relationship with food.I think there's certain textures that I would always avoid.Anything that's a bit, I dunno, slimy or strange,but I think if there's a lot going on in my lifeand everything else feels unpredictable,then I don't have the energy left to dealwith food being unpredictable either.So for example, if I've fallen out with a friendor if I've got really busy week at work,or if there's a lot going on, that all feels unpredictable.So if I'm then to eat a piece of fruit that might be crunchyor might be a bit soggy, that uncertaintyand that not getting what I expect is goingto tip me over the edge.So I tend to have certain foods that I know are always goingto give me the same thing.Like a chicken nugget is always goingto be a chicken nugget, A bagelis always going to be a bagel.It's quite predictable what you're going to get.It's less risk of that being the one thingthat's going to tip me over the edge.So even if I can't predict if my friend's going to fall outwith me, if my project's going to go well at work,if I'm going to be tired from doing something, I still knowthat a bagel is a bagel.And I think a lot of autistic people have these kindof safe foods that they return back towhen things feel like a lot.I think another thing that we strugglewith is getting the signals from our bodies.So whereas a normal person might get a natural signalof being hungry, my body kindof doesn't naturally tell me that.So if it's lunchtimeand then everybody else is eating, then I kindof get the signal from everybody else eating that, oh,it's lunchtime, I must be hungry, I should eat.But if I am maybe alone at home, not around other peopleand I don't have that structure,then I won't naturally think to eat.I can just go and go and goand then suddenly think, ohmy goodness, I've not had any lunch.So I think the way the food that we eat can be more unusual,and I think the way that we know to eat can needreminders from the outside as well.
videos.subtitle:
﻿WEBVTT

00:00:00.805 --> 00:00:04.505
So this is something that I am very up and down with.

00:00:05.865 --> 00:00:09.465
I think for me it shows up in the way

00:00:09.465 --> 00:00:11.465
that I have certain safe foods.

00:00:12.525 --> 00:00:16.325
So I think the best way to describe it is

00:00:17.365 --> 00:00:19.565
a lot of the time, if I'm just going about my life,

00:00:19.825 --> 00:00:20.885
if I'm doing normal things,

00:00:20.955 --> 00:00:24.845
then I have a fairly normal relationship with food.

00:00:25.885 --> 00:00:28.445
I think there's certain textures that I would always avoid.

00:00:28.925 --> 00:00:31.565
Anything that's a bit, I dunno, slimy or strange,

00:00:32.585 --> 00:00:36.565
but I think if there's a lot going on in my life

00:00:36.825 --> 00:00:40.125
and everything else feels unpredictable,

00:00:40.675 --> 00:00:44.365
then I don't have the energy left to deal

00:00:44.365 --> 00:00:46.205
with food being unpredictable either.

00:00:47.665 --> 00:00:51.045
So for example, if I've fallen out with a friend

00:00:51.225 --> 00:00:52.805
or if I've got really busy week at work,

00:00:53.225 --> 00:00:57.405
or if there's a lot going on, that all feels unpredictable.

00:00:57.505 --> 00:01:02.325
So if I'm then to eat a piece of fruit that might be crunchy

00:01:02.425 --> 00:01:06.285
or might be a bit soggy, that uncertainty

00:01:06.305 --> 00:01:09.065
and that not getting what I expect is going

00:01:09.065 --> 00:01:10.405
to tip me over the edge.

00:01:11.105 --> 00:01:15.165
So I tend to have certain foods that I know are always going

00:01:15.165 --> 00:01:16.965
to give me the same thing.

00:01:17.515 --> 00:01:19.165
Like a chicken nugget is always going

00:01:19.165 --> 00:01:20.525
to be a chicken nugget, A bagel

00:01:20.745 --> 00:01:21.885
is always going to be a bagel.

00:01:22.435 --> 00:01:25.005
It's quite predictable what you're going to get.

00:01:25.915 --> 00:01:28.245
It's less risk of that being the one thing

00:01:28.245 --> 00:01:29.405
that's going to tip me over the edge.

00:01:29.585 --> 00:01:32.925
So even if I can't predict if my friend's going to fall out

00:01:32.925 --> 00:01:34.925
with me, if my project's going to go well at work,

00:01:35.945 --> 00:01:38.685
if I'm going to be tired from doing something, I still know

00:01:38.685 --> 00:01:39.965
that a bagel is a bagel.

00:01:40.705 --> 00:01:43.205
And I think a lot of autistic people have these kind

00:01:43.205 --> 00:01:44.925
of safe foods that they return back to

00:01:45.795 --> 00:01:47.085
when things feel like a lot.

00:01:48.085 --> 00:01:51.365
I think another thing that we struggle

00:01:51.365 --> 00:01:54.205
with is getting the signals from our bodies.

00:01:54.905 --> 00:01:59.405
So whereas a normal person might get a natural signal

00:01:59.465 --> 00:02:03.005
of being hungry, my body kind

00:02:03.005 --> 00:02:04.405
of doesn't naturally tell me that.

00:02:04.585 --> 00:02:06.445
So if it's lunchtime

00:02:06.825 --> 00:02:08.965
and then everybody else is eating, then I kind

00:02:08.965 --> 00:02:11.405
of get the signal from everybody else eating that, oh,

00:02:11.405 --> 00:02:13.285
it's lunchtime, I must be hungry, I should eat.

00:02:14.065 --> 00:02:17.725
But if I am maybe alone at home, not around other people

00:02:17.785 --> 00:02:19.005
and I don't have that structure,

00:02:19.715 --> 00:02:22.165
then I won't naturally think to eat.

00:02:23.005 --> 00:02:24.405
I can just go and go and go

00:02:24.405 --> 00:02:25.645
and then suddenly think, oh

00:02:25.645 --> 00:02:26.765
my goodness, I've not had any lunch.

00:02:27.705 --> 00:02:32.085
So I think the way the food that we eat can be more unusual,

00:02:32.305 --> 00:02:36.465
and I think the way that we know to eat can need

00:02:37.185 --> 00:02:38.385
reminders from the outside as well.
videos.description: Safe foods and eating routines explained

collections.name: Flip the fear
collections.description: Olympians, pros, and a brain expert break down what nerves really are, and how to stop them from hijacking your day.

videos.question: Is there any calming exercises you can show me? Two sharp breaths
videos.transcription: Yes.So we're going to do an exercise that helpsyou calm down a little bit.By activating the vagus nerve, it's also goingto give a bit more oxygen to the brain, so a bit more fuelso your brain doesn't feel a little bit worried.And it's also going to move your spine a little bitbecause it, you move your spine,your diaphragm attaches in there, your ribcage, all ofthat stuff's going to move and just startfiring a little bit more.So what we're going to do, first of all, is we're goingto just focus on moving the spine part.Most people do find it hardto move the spine without moving their shoulders.So we're going to use our hand as feedback.So I'm going to put my hand in the centre of my chestand push my chest bone away,and then I'm going to use my chest boneto push my hand away.So it's flexion extension.What we're going to do is we're going to addtwo sharp breaths in and one loud exhale out.And this is where things like the vagus nerveand the oxygen to the brain come in.Okay, so we're going to go And then two sharp bes.So you want to do about three to five reps of that.And what that's going to do is it's goingto improve fuel to the brain.It's going to fire up. The information come fromthat vagus nerve, the wander nerve all throughout the body.That's what the wee hum is doing.And it's going to move your diaphragm, it's goingto move your lungs, your ribcage, all of thatwith the spinal movement.All of these are going to help makethat brain feel a little bit calmerand a little bit more at home and safer in your environment.
videos.subtitle:
﻿WEBVTT

00:00:00.755 --> 00:00:00.975
Yes.

00:00:01.195 --> 00:00:03.895
So we're going to do an exercise that helps

00:00:04.555 --> 00:00:06.095
you calm down a little bit.

00:00:06.115 --> 00:00:09.295
By activating the vagus nerve, it's also going

00:00:09.295 --> 00:00:12.255
to give a bit more oxygen to the brain, so a bit more fuel

00:00:12.475 --> 00:00:14.335
so your brain doesn't feel a little bit worried.

00:00:14.755 --> 00:00:17.535
And it's also going to move your spine a little bit

00:00:17.645 --> 00:00:19.655
because it, you move your spine,

00:00:20.445 --> 00:00:23.175
your diaphragm attaches in there, your ribcage, all of

00:00:23.175 --> 00:00:24.855
that stuff's going to move and just start

00:00:24.875 --> 00:00:25.935
firing a little bit more.

00:00:26.435 --> 00:00:28.655
So what we're going to do, first of all, is we're going

00:00:28.655 --> 00:00:30.695
to just focus on moving the spine part.

00:00:31.125 --> 00:00:32.455
Most people do find it hard

00:00:32.455 --> 00:00:35.015
to move the spine without moving their shoulders.

00:00:35.035 --> 00:00:36.935
So we're going to use our hand as feedback.

00:00:37.355 --> 00:00:40.215
So I'm going to put my hand in the centre of my chest

00:00:40.355 --> 00:00:42.295
and push my chest bone away,

00:00:43.195 --> 00:00:44.775
and then I'm going to use my chest bone

00:00:44.775 --> 00:00:46.175
to push my hand away.

00:00:46.755 --> 00:00:48.935
So it's flexion extension.

00:00:50.205 --> 00:00:51.655
What we're going to do is we're going to add

00:00:52.195 --> 00:00:56.815
two sharp breaths in and one loud exhale out.

00:00:56.915 --> 00:00:58.615
And this is where things like the vagus nerve

00:00:58.615 --> 00:01:00.415
and the oxygen to the brain come in.

00:01:00.415 --> 00:01:05.295
Okay, so we're going to go And then two sharp bes.

00:01:15.325 --> 00:01:18.265
So you want to do about three to five reps of that.

00:01:18.925 --> 00:01:20.445
And what that's going to do is it's going

00:01:20.445 --> 00:01:21.705
to improve fuel to the brain.

00:01:22.295 --> 00:01:24.105
It's going to fire up. The information come from

00:01:24.105 --> 00:01:26.705
that vagus nerve, the wander nerve all throughout the body.

00:01:26.705 --> 00:01:27.985
That's what the wee hum is doing.

00:01:28.165 --> 00:01:30.465
And it's going to move your diaphragm, it's going

00:01:30.465 --> 00:01:32.425
to move your lungs, your ribcage, all of that

00:01:32.975 --> 00:01:34.585
with the spinal movement.

00:01:35.005 --> 00:01:36.945
All of these are going to help make

00:01:36.945 --> 00:01:38.625
that brain feel a little bit calmer

00:01:38.685 --> 00:01:41.665
and a little bit more at home and safer in your environment.
videos.description: Calming exercise using breath and spine movement

videos.question: How did you cope with your nerves?
videos.transcription: Through experience, I learned howto deal with 'em a little bit better.Probably the main thingthat I wish I'd done was have someonethat I could talk about it openly with.I felt like I was the only player that was feeling the waythat I did, but when you come out of it,when you get a bit olderand you talk to other players,everyone's going through the same thing.They're probably just hiding it in different ways.So knowing that I wasn't the only one feelingthat way would've been nice.And then just having someone that you can openly expressthat with that can help youso you're not just containing it all the timeand trying to deal with it on your own.
videos.subtitle:
﻿WEBVTT

00:00:01.875 --> 00:00:04.645
Through experience, I learned how

00:00:04.645 --> 00:00:05.725
to deal with 'em a little bit better.

00:00:07.165 --> 00:00:08.445
Probably the main thing

00:00:08.445 --> 00:00:10.165
that I wish I'd done was have someone

00:00:10.165 --> 00:00:11.645
that I could talk about it openly with.

00:00:12.285 --> 00:00:14.525
I felt like I was the only player that was feeling the way

00:00:14.525 --> 00:00:16.165
that I did, but when you come out of it,

00:00:16.165 --> 00:00:17.205
when you get a bit older

00:00:17.225 --> 00:00:18.325
and you talk to other players,

00:00:18.805 --> 00:00:19.845
everyone's going through the same thing.

00:00:19.915 --> 00:00:21.645
They're probably just hiding it in different ways.

00:00:22.185 --> 00:00:23.885
So knowing that I wasn't the only one feeling

00:00:23.885 --> 00:00:25.445
that way would've been nice.

00:00:26.265 --> 00:00:28.725
And then just having someone that you can openly express

00:00:28.725 --> 00:00:29.925
that with that can help you

00:00:30.345 --> 00:00:32.045
so you're not just containing it all the time

00:00:32.345 --> 00:00:33.445
and trying to deal with it on your own.
videos.description: Shared experiences help manage performance nerves

videos.question: How have you learnt to deal with nerves throughout your career?
videos.transcription: For myself, I think nerves were,and I was always very nervous if I hadn't prepared wellfor me, if I had prepared well in a week,I had done enough training, I had done my preparation.I was confident in my ability.I was confident in what I had amongst myself.However, if I had potentially had a little niggle in theweek and not trained all weekand only trained a little bit on Friday,and then going into a game,then I was really, really nervous.But I think also as well,whenever you played for England, there'd be nerves the daybefore all week you are a little bit nervousand you're kind of excited,but you were a little bit on edge.And then you get to Friday, you've done that last bitof training, and then you almost have this 24 hour windowof you're not really doing anything, you're having a bitof treatment, you might be travelling,and you're just trying to distract yourself.You're not trying to think about the game too much.So I might be mucking around with the restof the team in the games roomor the team room to watching a couple of silly films justto try and mentally switch offand hoping you can have a good night's sleep.It was always that night before the gamewhere sometimes in your head you are playing things through.And the night before game, I'd always like to go over moves,go over tactics in my head,and then switch off and kind of park that.So I think for me it was trying to distract yourselfwith good distractions.
videos.subtitle:
﻿WEBVTT

00:00:01.205 --> 00:00:02.705
For myself, I think nerves were,

00:00:03.445 --> 00:00:06.265
and I was always very nervous if I hadn't prepared well

00:00:07.205 --> 00:00:09.425
for me, if I had prepared well in a week,

00:00:09.625 --> 00:00:12.785
I had done enough training, I had done my preparation.

00:00:13.465 --> 00:00:14.585
I was confident in my ability.

00:00:14.705 --> 00:00:17.025
I was confident in what I had amongst myself.

00:00:17.455 --> 00:00:20.225
However, if I had potentially had a little niggle in the

00:00:20.225 --> 00:00:21.785
week and not trained all week

00:00:21.845 --> 00:00:24.025
and only trained a little bit on Friday,

00:00:24.085 --> 00:00:25.145
and then going into a game,

00:00:25.415 --> 00:00:27.265
then I was really, really nervous.

00:00:29.205 --> 00:00:30.425
But I think also as well,

00:00:30.865 --> 00:00:33.105
whenever you played for England, there'd be nerves the day

00:00:33.105 --> 00:00:34.745
before all week you are a little bit nervous

00:00:34.805 --> 00:00:36.825
and you're kind of excited,

00:00:37.005 --> 00:00:38.065
but you were a little bit on edge.

00:00:38.145 --> 00:00:40.025
And then you get to Friday, you've done that last bit

00:00:40.025 --> 00:00:43.125
of training, and then you almost have this 24 hour window

00:00:43.185 --> 00:00:45.885
of you're not really doing anything, you're having a bit

00:00:45.885 --> 00:00:47.525
of treatment, you might be travelling,

00:00:48.585 --> 00:00:49.965
and you're just trying to distract yourself.

00:00:49.965 --> 00:00:51.725
You're not trying to think about the game too much.

00:00:52.625 --> 00:00:55.885
So I might be mucking around with the rest

00:00:55.885 --> 00:00:57.565
of the team in the games room

00:00:57.585 --> 00:01:01.005
or the team room to watching a couple of silly films just

00:01:01.005 --> 00:01:02.205
to try and mentally switch off

00:01:03.065 --> 00:01:05.005
and hoping you can have a good night's sleep.

00:01:05.325 --> 00:01:06.685
It was always that night before the game

00:01:06.685 --> 00:01:09.565
where sometimes in your head you are playing things through.

00:01:09.585 --> 00:01:13.485
And the night before game, I'd always like to go over moves,

00:01:13.585 --> 00:01:14.805
go over tactics in my head,

00:01:15.665 --> 00:01:17.565
and then switch off and kind of park that.

00:01:18.385 --> 00:01:20.925
So I think for me it was trying to distract yourself

00:01:20.955 --> 00:01:22.325
with good distractions.
videos.description: Preparation and distraction before big events

videos.question: Do you get nervous before a big match?
videos.transcription: Yeah, I still do.Even at my age, I still get nervous.I don't think there's anything wrong with that.I think it sort of shows you care.You care about the event that's coming.So being nervous is not something that you shouldshy away from or think is a negative.I think those nerves are, as longas you learn to challenge them, right?And I reckon they can add to your performance.So I used to sort of like it when I felt a bit nervous.I knew that I was most really getting ready for a big one.So, yeah, I enjoyed it.
videos.subtitle:
﻿WEBVTT

00:00:00.285 --> 00:00:01.335
Yeah, I still do.

00:00:01.335 --> 00:00:02.775
Even at my age, I still get nervous.

00:00:03.495 --> 00:00:04.775
I don't think there's anything wrong with that.

00:00:05.655 --> 00:00:06.855
I think it sort of shows you care.

00:00:06.995 --> 00:00:09.335
You care about the event that's coming.

00:00:09.435 --> 00:00:13.255
So being nervous is not something that you should

00:00:13.955 --> 00:00:15.695
shy away from or think is a negative.

00:00:16.855 --> 00:00:18.775
I think those nerves are, as long

00:00:18.775 --> 00:00:19.975
as you learn to challenge them, right?

00:00:19.975 --> 00:00:22.015
And I reckon they can add to your performance.

00:00:22.035 --> 00:00:24.335
So I used to sort of like it when I felt a bit nervous.

00:00:24.975 --> 00:00:27.215
I knew that I was most really getting ready for a big one.

00:00:27.235 --> 00:00:28.535
So, yeah, I enjoyed it.
